Replace.Text: For this Age, gain +15% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] at the cost of -2 Combat Strength for your Naval Units
For this Age, +3 Combat Strength for your Naval Units at the cost of -10% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY]
For this Age, gain +15% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] at the cost of -2 Combat Strength for your Air Units
For this Age, +3 Combat Strength for your Air Units at the cost of -10% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY]
Legend Unlock. +25% Relationship from starting or supporting Endeavors. -25% Relationship from starting Sanctions or rejecting Endeavors.
Legend Unlock. +5 Combat Strength for all Units against Districts.

Jhansi was a small state in north-central India, historically independent and bolstered by alliances with powerful empires nearby, particularly the Mughals. In 1740, Jhansi became part of the Maratha Empire, which soon transitioned into indirect rule by the East India Company. Under European supervision, when a Jhansi raja died, his successor had to be approved by British administrators. After this regulation was instated, the first few transfers of power between rulers, who were all blood related (father to son, brother to brother), went uncontested.

But in 1853, Raja Gangadhar Rao lay dying with no heir and no siblings who could rightfully take his throne. As was custom in these situations, he adopted a boy, his cousin’s son Damodar Rao, on his deathbed and named him his successor. A British officer bore witness to this ceremony, and Gangadhar Rao wrote a letter explaining the legitimacy of the adoption by Jhansi tradition. Seeing an opportunity for expansion, the British chose not to recognize Damodar Rao as a legitimate heir upon Gangadhar Rao’s death. Instead, they declared the throne empty and annexed the state.
But they didn’t count on Gangadhar Rao’s wife.

Lakshmibai was the name given to her after marriage – she was born Manikarnika Tambe in 1835 and was raised in the household of Maratha ruler Baji Rao II, whom her soldier father served. Her upbringing was unusual. She learned to read and write at an early age, but she was primarily raised alongside the boys in the royal court. As a result, she also trained with them in sports and martial arts, including wrestling, fencing, and shooting. She was particularly skilled in horsemanship, and managed her own horses throughout her life.

Her marriage to Raja Gangadhar Rao lasted just over a decade, and upon his death and the British takeover, she was forced out of the palace with her adopted son. She lay low for several years, aware that the British held all the cards and that to oppose them at this time would be futile. Yet she maintained a presence among her populace as the mother of their rightful ruler, and her charismatic persona earned her respect from all quarters.

In 1857, the Indian Rebellion began in Meerut, north of Delhi. Subsequent victories against the British proved the power behind the uprising, and Lakshmibai seized the opportunity to join the cause and take back her kingdom. She raised her own troops and joined the revolt when rebel soldiers arrived in Jhansi, capturing the British fort and massacring its European garrison and their families. Her contested role in this violence – it is unclear whether she took part or if incoming soldiers committed the atrocities – earned her negative press from the British, but she continued to fund the rebels. Her young son Damodar Rao was formally declared raja of Jhansi, and Lakshmibai was named regent.

After only a short hiatus, the British returned to reclaim Jhansi in early 1858, initiating a siege that lasted several months until Lakshmibai’s forces could no longer hold out. A popular story has her escaping the fort by jumping over the wall on horseback with her son on her back, and a sign marks the spot at Jhansi Fort today. She continued her resistance in the aftermath, rallying troops and fighting in battles herself, often dressed as a man. But her forces suffered further defeat, and Lakshmibai was killed in combat on June 17 at the age of only 22. It took a further five months for the British to regain full control of Jhansi.
Weapons possess only the power of those who wield them, and that power comes from the heart.
I am Rani Lakshmibai, defender of liberty and mother to my people.
I am Rani Lakshmibai, defender of liberty and mother to my people.
I am Rani Lakshmibai, defender of liberty and mother to my people.
Your plague of demons will meet a swift end.
As a mother defends her child, so I will defend my empire against your depravity.
Baadal, bear me hence our fight here is done.
May our work together bear many fruits.
Ha! As if I would agree to that!

+50% [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence towards initiating the [icon:CITYSTATE] City-State - Incorporate Action. When you incorporate a City-State, you gain all of their Units. When one of your Land Military Units defeats an enemy Unit, gain [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence equal to 100% of the defeated Unit's [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength.

[BLIST][LI][B]+50% [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence [/B]towards initiating the [icon:CITYSTATE] [B]City-State - Incorporate[/B] Action.[LI]When you incorporate a [icon:CITYSTATE] [B]City-State [/B], you gain all of their Units.[LI]When one of your [B]Land Military Units [/B]defeats an enemy Unit, gain [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] [B]Influence [/B]equal to [B]100% [/B]of the defeated Unit's [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] [B]Combat Strength[/B].[/LIST]
Gain [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence equal to 25% of the defeated Unit's strength when in Command Radius.
Gain [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence equal to 25% of the defeated Unit's strength.
Gain Influence equal to 25% of the defeated Unit's strength.
Likes the Civilization with the highest[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence. Dislikes the one with the lowest[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence.

Lakshmibai, Rani of Jhansi, on the back of great Baadal, you come in a thunder of hooves - and you will not have your birthright denied. With raised saber, you call upon your people to defend what is theirs, and deny thieves and plunderers their prize. Stand, Rani, and show what it is to be a leader.
+2 Combat Strength defending in friendly territory.
+1 [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence per Age per Pasture Improvement.
+1 [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence per Age for each Commander Promotion.

As Lakshmibai, complete 2 Legacy Paths in a single Antiquity Age.

As Lakshmibai in Antiquity, complete a quest to impress an assassin.
As Lakshmibai in Antiquity, complete a quest to place soldiers in saddles.
As Lakshmibai in Exploration, complete a quest to cast a wide net of faith.
As Lakshmibai in Exploration, complete a quest to fortify settlements.
As Lakshmibai in Modern, complete a quest to demonstrate legitimacy through history.
As Lakshmibai in Modern, complete a quest to finish off our enemies.

Lakshmibai is a queen by birth, but rule can always be contested. As the messengers return from the battlefield, she considers — are grace and legal right enough for rule, or must all be changed to keep a hold on power?
The court has become the center of all that is good and beautiful in the world. At the center of the center: the Rani.
From the cooks to the latrine-emptiers, all stand for martial drills in the morning.
A story circulates in the palace about how a would-be assassin’s blade fell from his fingers as he gazed in awe at the architecture gracing Lakshmibai’s capital.
Who could dare invade, and risk scratching one stone of these marvels?
When the need for more warriors arose, they came from their fields and their washing, their brick-laying and their fire-tending. Now, they sit astride their mounts, weapons of war in their hands.
Now, perhaps now Lakshmibai may sleep safe.
Enough. Let others continue their labor.
The recent onslaught of diplomatic setbacks might have shattered a lesser Rani, but Lakshmibai’s will is unyielding — like iron tempered in fire.
Make a show of military power.

Lakshmibai, running Badaal at a full gallop, clears a training course flawlessly — to the thunderous applause of new recruits. Watching from the sides, cavalry officers decide which aspects to emphasize.
Lakshmibai runs her hand across Baadal’s mane. She feels the horse's heartbeat through its skin.
An era of change, of expansion and conquest, dawns. Lakshmibai, atop Baadal, rides a course around her city as her people cheer. Looking at them, she sees two paths forward.
In their eyes, there is confidence.
They must be armed against the coming age.
The title of Rani commands some, but faith can cast a wider net.
Lakshmibai's image appears in temples as the goddess of queenly authority. With royal majesty, it seems, comes divine right.
Convert 5 Settlements to follow your Religion.
A trade ship, its hull strangely carved, arrives in port. The sailors cannot speak the local language, but they know one word: Rani.
What was admiration can become faith.
Even separated by the salt sea, Lakshmibai gains followers.
Convert 4 Foreign Settlements in Distant Lands to follow your Religion.

In Lakshmibai's war council, a general unrolls a map, showing her forces and those of the enemy. The map is of the entire world; troops and ships cross the farthest distances in order to kill or be killed.
Lakshmibai will not tolerate foreign boots in her cities.
Send the battle to the enemy.
Men travel for months at sea only to disembark and die, for the ambitions of a few. Lakshmibai has entered the fray, and will end it.
Send their nobility home in caskets.
Free Commander Promotion on highest level Commander.
The commander lies slain on the battlefield, as Lakshmibai's warriors make a respectful circle. This is not only a victory; it is a message.
Defeat a Commander from a Distant Lands Player in Distant Lands.

In a cloister garden, wide-eyed students listen to Lakshmibai recount her rigorous upbringing — a blend of reading, writing, horsemanship, and mallakhamba. One student wonders whether they can master both mind and body, as the Rani clearly has done.
Knowledge is the bedrock of greatness.
Those with skilled hands shape the world.

The foundations of a village have been reduced to rubble. Lakshmibai, the architect of this devastation, extends a hand of mercy to its survivors, offering them the chance to rebuild something greater.
Their talents are required in the countryside.
They may pledge their strength to Lakshmibai.
The sweet scent of incense and marigolds hangs over a funeral march honoring warriors who sacrificed their lives for their homeland. The procession stops in front of Lakshmibai.
Celebrate the fallen with a feast.
As {1_Capital} rapidly expands, Lakshmibai summons her council, urging bold measures to keep pace with the relentless growth.
The question of legitimacy is solved in the end by persistence. The world has seen profound shifts, but Lakshmibai remains: steadfast, regal, a Rani.
Show the weight of history, and her constancy.
Lakshmibai has nothing to prove. Her grace is self-evident.
Lakshmibai gains focus as the contours of the world's alliances and rivalries become clear. Now, friends and foes stand in stark relief.
Let our enemies know who they are.
Lakshmibai has nothing to prove. Her might is self-evident.

Lakshmibai’s eyes flick over the formal petition from {1_INDEPENDENT_CS}. The city-state insists that Lakshmibai's enemies are an imminent threat, but she knows that granting aid could jeopardize the fragile welfare of the {2_Civilization_adj} people.
Put the well-being of the {1_Civilization_adj} people first.
Despite their recent victory, soldiers crouch hollow-eyed in the wreckage of the battlefield. Their commander urges them forward, but they remain listless.
Orders are orders. They will move with haste.
Send a stipend to their families.
Spread the word of their victory.

With a single stroke of her quill, Lakshmibai seals a dearly bought peace. Having stood as the {1_CIVILIZATION_adj} people's unyielding protector, she now swears to be their steadfast guide and caretaker.
The young must be ready to face hardship.

Lakshmibai’s agents arrive with the moonlight, eager to receive her next coded missive. {1_Independent} has been both sword and shield for the {2_Civilization_adj} people, but Lakshmibai knows the fight is far from over.
Pillaging gives[icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold equal to 25% of the yield or healing.
Pillaging gives[icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science equal to 25% of the yield or healing.
Arrows hiss past Baadal's reins as Lakshmibai makes a daring moonlit escape from a city on fire. Lakshmibai's enemies may have captured her home, but she remains indomitable.
Lakshmibai catches one child raising a fist against another. After she grabs both of them by the wrists, she explains how the {1_Civilization_adj} people should solve their disputes.

Lakshmibai's blade flashes in the sunlight as she executes a series of precise moves in the courtyard. A passing official arches an eyebrow, curious about her dedication to the martial arts in an age ruled by firepower.
The sword is a symbol more than a tool.
In a master's hands, the blade is deadly.

As war breaks out, Lakshmibai considers its justifications. A British advisor offers a suggestion — he could produce a very plausible forgery invalidating the enemy's right to rule a particular city. She considers...
This is not how Lakshmibai rules.
As Lakshmibai, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +15% Influence, -2 Combat Strength for Naval Units
As Lakshmibai, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength towards Naval Units, -10% Influence
As Lakshmibai, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +15% Influence, -2 Combat Strength for Air Units
As Lakshmibai, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength towards Air Units, -10% Influence
+5 Combat Strength for all Units against Districts.
+25% Relationship from starting or supporting Endeavors. -25% Relationship from starting Sanctions or rejecting Endeavors.
[B]Lakshmibai[/B] was from the same region as [B]Maurya[/B].
[B]Lakshmibai[/B] was from the same continent as [B]Chola[/B].
[B]Lakshmibai[/B] was from the same region as the [B]Mughal[/B].
